body:
Hi, sorry for taking so long to reply.

Can you provide an example where this causes you problems? I think we already have a mechanism for overriding the builtin decorators that pylint can understand (property-classes if I am remembering correctly).
I have basically the same issue, but I get a E1101 (no-member) because I'm returning an object, which I then access a member on.

`hybrid_property` doesn't inherit from `property`, so we would have to look for a [property-like interface](https://docs.python.org/3.6/howto/descriptor.html#properties) to support duck typing.

Although my guess is that `_is_property_decorator` (https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/blob/fbdf5ba095ebbbf04db12f6c3e88e21152a30507/pylint/checkers/utils.py#L500) cannot infer `hybrid_property`, and so it assumes that it isn't a property.
Not really sure how we can go about this without adding a configurable whitelist of property names.

issue.title: False positive: no-member on "property"-like decorator

labels.name: Duplicate üê´
labels.description: Duplicate of an already existing issue

labels.name: False Positive ü¶ü
labels.description: A message is emitted but nothing is wrong with the code

repository.name: pylint
repository.description: It's not just a linter that annoys you!

issue.body:
### Steps to reproduce
1. Have Pylint (1.6.4) evaluate the following snippet:
   
   ``` python
   class prop(object):
       def __init__(self, fn):
           self.value = 5
   
   class my_class(object):
       @prop
       def my_property(self):
           pass
   
   print(my_class().my_property.value)
   ```
### Current behavior

Pylint returns the following, even with `prop` added to `property_classes`:
    `E: 10, 6: Method 'my_property' has no 'value' member (no-member)`
### Expected behavior

No `no-member` errors. A decorated function should not be assumed to be a function.
### `pylint --version` output

```
    No config file found, using default configuration
    pylint 1.6.4, 
    astroid 1.4.8
    Python 3.5.2 (default, Jun 28 2016, 08:46:01) 
    [GCC 6.1.1 20160602]
```

body:
Flask has introduced [`flask.helpers.locked_cached_property`](https://github.com/pallets/flask/blob/master/flask/helpers.py#L840) which similarly decorates methods so they behave as properties:

```python
    @locked_cached_property
    def logger(self):
        return create_logger(self)
```

As I read the documentation, you _should_ be able to set `property-classes` to tell pylint about these decorators, but I can't get it to work.

```
# List of decorators that produce properties, such as abc.abstractproperty. Add
# to this list to register other decorators that produce valid properties.
property-classes = abc.abstractproperty, flask.helpers.locked_cached_property
```

```
$ pipenv run pylint unixtimestamp.py 
Loading .env environment variables‚Ä¶
Using config file /Users/craiga/unixtimesta.mp/.pylintrc
************* Module unixtimestamp
E: 19, 0: Method 'logger' has no 'addHandler' member (no-member)
E: 20, 0: Method 'logger' has no 'setLevel' member (no-member)
E: 54, 8: Method 'logger' has no 'info' member (no-member)
E: 87, 8: Method 'logger' has no 'info' member (no-member)
E:183, 8: Method 'logger' has no 'info' member (no-member)
E:223, 4: Method 'logger' has no 'info' member (no-member)

------------------------------------------------------------------
Your code has been rated at 7.27/10 (previous run: 7.27/10, +0.00)
```

Providing the module that contains the property decorator is discoverable and inferable by pylint, this issue should now be resolved.
For all other cases, unfortunately configuration options are not shareable between checkers. The checker that defines `property-classes` is different to the one that raises E0202, so E0202 cannot use the whitelist of property names. This issue is being resolved as part of the per directory config project though, so I'm closing this issue with the partial fix in place.

issue.title: Applying the property decorator indirectly cause pylint to report E0202.

repository.name: pylint
repository.description: It's not just a linter that annoys you!

issue.body:
<!--
  Hi there! Thank you for discovering and submitting an issue.

  Before you submit this, make sure that the issue doesn't already exist
  or if it is not closed.

  Is your issue fixed on the preview release?: pip install pylint astroid --pre -U

-->
### Problem
Applying the property decorator indirectly may cause pylint to report [E0202].

### Steps to reproduce
```python3
class MyProperty(property):
    def __get__(self, obj, obj_type=None):
        print('get via MyProperty, the method is not hidden.')
        return super(MyProperty, self).__get__(obj, obj_type)

    def __set__(self, obj, value):
        print('set via MyProperty, the method is not hidden.')
        super(MyProperty, self).__set__(obj, value)


def my_decorator(*args, **kwargs):
    return MyProperty(*args, **kwargs)


class Foo:
    def __init__(self):
        self._bar = 42
        self._baz = 84

    @MyProperty
    def bar(self):  # OK
        return self._bar

    @bar.setter
    def bar(self, value):
        self._bar = value

    def do_something_with_bar(self, value):
        self.bar = value  # OK

    @my_decorator
    def baz(self):  # E0202
        return self._baz

    @baz.setter
    def baz(self, value):
        self._baz = value

    def do_something_with_baz(self, value):
        self.baz = value  # E0202 caused by this line.


def test():
    foo = Foo()

    foo.bar = 123
    foo.do_something_with_bar(456)
    foo.bar = 789
    assert foo._bar == 789

    foo.baz = 123
    foo.do_something_with_baz(456)
    foo.baz = 789
    assert foo._baz == 789


if __name__ == '__main__':
    test()

```

### Current behavior
Pylint reports [E0202] due to the line inside the `do_something_with_baz()` function, while the one in the `do_something_with_bar()` is alright.

The behavior of the `bar` and the `baz` should be nearly identical in this case. Therefore, I think this is a falsy positive.

The output of this code is, as expected, 6 lines of:
```
set via MyProperty, the method is not hidden.
```
No assertion error was raised.

I have tried adding the custom property classes to `property-classes` in `.pylintrc` file like this:
```
# List of decorators that produce properties, such as abc.abstractproperty. Add
# to this list to register other decorators that produce valid properties.
property-classes=abc.abstractproperty,
                 MyProperty,
                 my_decorator
```
and the message still presented.

An equivalence code which won't cause [E0202]:
```python3
class MyProperty(property):
    def __get__(self, obj, obj_type=None):
        print('get via MyProperty, method is not hidden.')
        return super(MyProperty, self).__get__(obj, obj_type)

    def __set__(self, obj, value):
        print('set via MyProperty, method is not hidden.')
        super(MyProperty, self).__set__(obj, value)


def my_decorator(*args, **kwargs):
    return MyProperty(*args, **kwargs)


class Foo:
    def __init__(self):
        self._bar = 42
        self._baz = 84

    def _get_bar(self):
        return self._bar

    def _set_bar(self, value):
        self._bar = value

    def _get_baz(self):
        return self._baz

    def _set_baz(self, value):
        self._baz = value

    bar = MyProperty(fget=_get_bar, fset=_set_bar)  # OK
    baz = my_decorator(fget=_get_baz, fset=_set_baz)  # OK

    def do_something_with_bar(self, value):
        self.bar = value  # OK

    def do_something_with_baz(self, value):
        self.baz = value  # OK


def test():
    foo = Foo()

    foo.bar = 123
    foo.do_something_with_bar(456)
    foo.bar = 789
    assert foo._bar == 789

    foo.baz = 123
    foo.do_something_with_baz(456)
    foo.baz = 789
    assert foo._baz == 789


if __name__ == '__main__':
    test()

```

### Expected behavior
No [E0202] for the above code.

Besides, according to the example which was found from [here](http://pylint-messages.wikidot.com/messages:e0202)

    a class defines a method and a client sets an instance attribute with the same name.

I expected the following code will cause the [E0202] for `hello`, but [E1102] was reported instead.
```python3
class MyClass:
    def __init__(self, value):
        self._value = value

    def hello(self):
        print('hello', self._value)


def test():
    c = MyClass(42)
    c.hello()  # E1102:c.hello is not callable
    c.hello = 123
    # c.hello()  # TypeError: 'int' object is not callable


if __name__ == '__main__':
    test()
```

### pylint --version output
```
pylint 2.0.1
astroid 2.0.1
Python 3.6.6 (v3.6.6:4cf1f54eb7, Jun 27 2018, 03:37:03) [MSC v.1900 64 bit (AMD64)]
```

### Related issues
I think this may relate to the following issues:
+ #414 False positive for E0202 (method-hidden)
+ #1061 SQLAlchemy @hybrid_property decorator not supported

[E0202]: https://github.com/pchomik/linter-python-doc/blob/master/errors/pylint.md#e0202
[E1102]: https://github.com/pchomik/linter-python-doc/blob/master/errors/pylint.md#e1102

body:
@AWhetter The case of sqlalchemy's hybrid_property (and hybrid_method) is more complex than what has been discussed here: It behaves differently when used on class and instance level see https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/orm/extensions/hybrid.html#module-sqlalchemy.ext.hybrid

Do you see how these could be supported in pylint?

See here an example how different instance-level and class-level behaviour is defined: https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/orm/extensions/hybrid.html#defining-expression-behavior-distinct-from-attribute-behavior
Having same issue here with `@hybrid_property` resulting in `E1101` despite setting `property-classes=abc.abstractproperty, sqlalchemy.ext.hybrid.hybrid_property`

issue.title: Incorrect E1101 (no-member) using SQLAlchemy @hybrid_property

labels.name: Needs astroid Brain üß†
labels.description: Needs a brain tip in astroid (then an astroid upgrade)

repository.name: pylint
repository.description: It's not just a linter that annoys you!

issue.body:
<!--
  Hi there! Thank you for discovering and submitting an issue.

  Before you submit this, make sure that the issue doesn't already exist
  or if it is not closed.

  Is your issue fixed on the preview release?: pip install pylint astroid --pre -U

-->

### Steps to reproduce
1. Reproducing code [wrong_no_member.txt](https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/files/4037739/wrong_no_member.txt)

```
from sqlalchemy import Column, Boolean
from sqlalchemy.ext.declarative import declarative_base
from sqlalchemy.ext.hybrid import hybrid_property
from sqlalchemy.schema import PrimaryKeyConstraint

Base = declarative_base()


class Table(Base):
    __tablename__ = 'table'
    __table_args__ = (PrimaryKeyConstraint('column1'),)
    _column1 = Column('column1', Boolean)
    column2 = Column('column2', Boolean)

    @hybrid_property
    def column1(self):
        return self._column1

    @column1.setter
    def column1(self, column1):
        self._column1 = column1


Table.column1.op('*')
Table.column2.op('*')
```
2. Just run as `pylint wrong_no_member.py`
### Current behavior
Complains about `column1`, `wrong_no_member.py:24:0: E1101: Method 'column1' has no 'op' member (no-member)`

### Expected behavior
No errors

### pylint --version output
```
$ pylint --version
pylint 2.4.4
astroid 2.3.3
Python 3.6.6 (default, May 14 2019, 11:57:55)
[GCC 7.4.0]
```

There's a few other issues in this repo and the astroid repo about various issues with properties, https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/issues/1061 is probably the closest.

issue.title: SQLAlchemy @hybrid_property.expression has "no-self-argument"

labels.name: Needs astroid Brain üß†
labels.description: Needs a brain tip in astroid (then an astroid upgrade)

labels.name: False Positive ü¶ü
labels.description: A message is emitted but nothing is wrong with the code

labels.name: Lib specific üíÖ
labels.description: This affect the code from a particular library

labels.name: Needs PR
labels.description: This issue is accepted, sufficiently specified and now needs an implementation

repository.name: pylint
repository.description: It's not just a linter that annoys you!

issue.body:
<!--
  Hi there! Thank you for discovering and submitting an issue.

  Before you submit this, make sure that the issue doesn't already exist
  or if it is not closed.

  Is your issue fixed on the preview release?: pip install pylint astroid --pre -U

-->

I'm not sure if this would be within the scope of `pylint` features, but a [similar question](https://github.com/PyCQA/pylint/issues/1061) was looked at previously, so I may as well mention the problem.

The `hybrid_property` of SQLAlchemy has an `expression` method, which acts like a classmethod in that it takes `cls` as an argument, not `self`. Pylint doesn't like this, and comes up with the `no-self-argument` warning. The documentation for it is [here](https://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/13/orm/extensions/hybrid.html#defining-expression-behavior-distinct-from-attribute-behavior).

Here's an example:

```python
from sqlalchemy import Column, Integer, func
from sqlalchemy.ext.declarative import declarative_base
from sqlalchemy.ext.hybrid import hybrid_property

Base = declarative_base()


class Test(Base):
    __tablename__ = 'test'

    id = Column(Integer, primary_key=True)
    name = Column(String(64), nullable=False)

    @hybrid_property
    def name_lower(self):
        return self.name.lower()

    @name_lower.expression
    def name_lower(cls, value):     # this line has the issue
        return func.lower(cls.name)
```

From a look at the source code, there doesn't seem to be an obvious way to detecting that though, so it may need to be more of a hardcoded feature if implemented.

body:
And we're having the same issue with `W0143 comparison-with-callable` despite having configured in out `pyproject.toml`:

```toml
[tool.pylint.basic]
property-classes = ["abc.abstractproperty", "sqlalchemy.ext.hybrid.hybrid_property"]
```
